Lucreţiu Pătrăşcanu, comunistul care nu semăna deloc cu ''parveniţii'' din PCR
03 Nov 2019, 22:00 by Redactia Descopera.ro



La 4 noiembrie 1900 s-a născut Lucreţiu Pătrăşcanu, conducător al Partidului Comunist Român, ministru, avocat, sociolog şi economist (d. 17 aprilie 1954)
Despre Lucretiu Patrascanu se poate spune orice, mai putin ca nu a fost un patriot pana in maduva oaselor. Departe de a se asemana cu parvenitii care gasisera in Partidul Comunist o forma de a avansa cat mai rapid pe scara sociala, Patrascanu era un om de o cultura deosebita.
Avocat, sociolog, economist, el a imbratisat doctrina comunista inca din timpul studentiei (1919), optand pentru un socialism de factura nationalista.
Declaratiile sale patriotarde, asa cum este cea de la Harkov (1928) prin care sustinea ca basarabenii sunt romani, sau replica memorabila de la Cluj (1946) "Inainte de a fi comunist, sunt roman!" i-au atras antipatia propriilor colegi de partid dar, mai ales, pe cea a Moscovei.
Este acuzat de nationalism burghez, de legaturi cu legionarii si este arestat in anul 1948. Sase ani mai tarziu, in 1954, a fost condamnat la moarte si executat, si asta dupa ce, in arest, ceruse sa isi continue munca in slujba Partidului Comunist chiar din celula in care fusese inchis.

Lucreţiu Pătrăşcanu, the Communist who did not resemble the PCRM's "parents"
03 Nov 2019, 22:00 by Redactia Descopera.ro



On November 4, 1900, Lucreţiu Pătrăşcanu was born, leader of the Romanian Communist Party, minister, lawyer, sociologist and economist (d. April 17, 1954).
About Lucretiu Patrascanu can say anything, except he was not a patriot until the bone marrow. Far from resembling those who had found in the Communist Party a way of advancing as quickly as possible on the social scale, Patrascanu was a man of a special culture.
Lawyer, sociologist, economist, he embraced the communist doctrine from the time he was a student (1919), opting for a socialism of nationalist nature.
His patriotic statements, such as that of Kharkov (1928), which claimed that the Bessarabians were Romanians, or a memorable reply from Cluj (1946) "Before I am a communist, I am Romanian!" they attracted the dislike of their party colleagues, but especially that of Moscow.
He is accused of bourgeois nationalism, of links with the legionaries and was arrested in 1948. Six years later, in 1954, he was sentenced to death and executed, and this after being arrested, he was asked to continue his work for the Communist Party. even from the cell in which it had been closed.
